Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: "Valleytronic Materials, Applications, and Devices" to be held at Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, MA August 22-23, 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The Workshop on "Valleytronic Materials, Applications, and Devices" will be held at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, MA on 22-23 August, 2017. It will focus on a class of devices and will host leading Valleytronics researchers in the field whose expertise range from synthesis, characterizations, device development, theory and applications. The devices make use of the momentum state of charge carriers instead of, or in combination with, charge and/or spin and are expected to provide a new degree of freedom for information processing. The Workshop seeks financial support to allow extension of the conference to include student and postdoc attendees, a student poster session, a student/postdoc lunch and a Q&A session, and a half day extension to the workshop to develop a draft of a whitepaper in the area of valleytronics. The meeting will be attended by graduate students as both an educational opportunity (similar to a 2-day short-course in Valleytronics) and as an opportunity to interact with senior researchers to whom they otherwise may not have access at larger symposia. A poster session is also planned for graduate students and postdocs to present their work related to the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Valleytronic Materials, Applications, and Devices Workshop was held at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, MA August 22-23, 2017. The goal of the workshop was to gather an international assembly of leading researchers in the field of two dimensional materials to discuss the opportunities and challenges of developing useful valleytronics technology. In many crystalline solids, there exist valleys in the conduction (valence) band which confine electrons (holes) in momentum space. In most materials there exists no practical way of addressing or manipulating these momentum states, for example in the case of multiple degenerate valleys electrons simply populate all the valleys uniformly. However in certain 2D materials such as graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides there is unique new physics enabled by the symmetry of these materials. In this case one can address and manipulate particles in these valleys independently. Now one can conceive of new device technologies based on this valley physics. For example, a particle in the K momentum valley may represent a logical "1" and a particle in the -K momentum valley may represent a logical "0". Thus it may be possible to exploit valleytronic technology for a revolutionary new paradigm in classical or quantum information processing.

               The workshop was extremely successful. Registration reached the venue capacity within three days of opening the registration website. Essentially all of the leading researchers in the field of valleytronics were in attendance. Sixteen speakers presented the latest research in the field, much of which was new, unpublished data. Postdocs and students had the opportunity to present their work in a poster session which offered a unique chance to interact with senior researchers in an intimate and collegial setting. Most importantly, half of the workshop was dedicated to working groups which discussed opportunities to move the field forward. The focus of the discussions was on pushing toward technological applications. The group identified numerous opportunities, including valleytronic accelerators for low power classical computing, high-coherence spin-protected valley qubits for quantum information processing, spin-lasers for quantum communication, valley-protected spin injection for practical spintronic devices, and microphotonic optical isolators.

               There have been two tangible outputs from the workshop. The first is a whitepaper which was distributed to attendees, to DoD agencies through Lincoln Laboratory, and to the public through the conference website. The second is a refined version of the whitepaper which was published in the journal Micro Nano Small. Both of these publications are not simply reviews of the field, but instead provide a critical analysis of the practical opportunities for valleytronic devices with an honest assessment of the challenges that lie ahead. These documents should provide a framework to focus future government sponsored research programs in valleytronics in meaningful and relevant directions.
